value.textLabel: C++ is an object-oriented, high-level, high-performance language. It compiles directly to machine code, giving developers fine-grained control over hardware and memory. It is a 'write once, compile anywhere' language.

C++ is widely used because:
• Unmatched performance and speed
• Direct memory and hardware control
• Runs everything from OS to game engines
• Huge libraries (e.g., STL, Boost)
• Backed by decades of community support
To use C++, you need a C++ compiler. Common choices are G++ (part of GCC) or Clang. On Windows, you can install Visual Studio or MinGW (G++). After installation, verify it using the command:
C++ syntax defines rules on how C++ code must be written. C++ is case-sensitive, uses semicolons to end statements, and is built around functions and (optionally) classes.

Key C++ syntax elements:
• Functions (like main) hold code
• Functions perform actions
• Statements end with semicolons
• Blocks use curly braces
C++ I/O (Input / Output) allows you to interact with users. The iostream library (using std::cin and std::cout) is commonly used.

value.textLabel: C++ has a rich set of built-in data types, often called *fundamental types*.

Type casting converts a value from one type to another.
• Widening/Promotion (automatic)
• Narrowing (manual, can be unsafe)
Operators allow you to perform actions on variables. They include arithmetic, logical, comparison, bitwise, and more.
